chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So, we're getting an n. Thank you.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Without using any string methods, try to print the following.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So, print from 1 all the way to n.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So, for example, if your integer is 5,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: we want you to print 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 right next to each other.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: For example, oh, the example is here.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: n equals 5 and the program expects us to print 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So, if the user gives 1000 here,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: they want you to print from 1 to 1000 next to each other.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: I think that would be a crazy thing to do.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: But, well, if they ask for it.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So, let's make a new function and call it, for example,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: print consecutive numbers.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: How about that?

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: And give me a number and I will print the consecutive numbers for that.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: I'm putting the word pass here because Python is like,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: okay, he said pass means that he doesn't want to do anything right now,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: but he will start writing things later.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Why I did that is that I want you to remember that, for example,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: the type of 56 is an integer,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: but the type of 56, which is exactly the same thing,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: but it's not, is a string.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: This question wants us to return a string.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: If you look at that, it says,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: print the list of integers from 1 through n as a string.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: If the user says n equals 5,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: they don't want us to print 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: However, they want us to print 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 as a string.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So, that might be a bit confusing,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: but right now I'll tell you what it means.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Let's get rid of that.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Just have an empty cell. Beautiful.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Let's start writing our function.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: What we want to start, we want to start with an empty container,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: like a bowl that doesn't have anything in it.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Let's call it final string and let's put nothing in it.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: We're just saying that, hey, Python,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: final string is an empty string,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: because we know that these people want us to return a string.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: We're just going to make an empty bowl for the string.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Okay?

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Now, for i in range of 1 and number plus 1.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Let's use the word pass again, because I'm going to come back.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: I'm just putting pass here so that the code doesn't break

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: in case I run it.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: You might ask, what is this?

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Well, it's a for loop.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: If the user gives me 5 as n, the range of 1 to 5,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: I can't really print it unless I convert it into a list.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Okay, let's convert it to a list and then print it,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: because, sorry, Python doesn't easily show print range.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: You can see that. Let me just show you.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: It will not print anything.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: It will just say, oh, it's a range.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: No, I want you to print the list of that range.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: But the funny thing is that range from 1 to 5 does not include 5.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Keep that in your mind.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: This is always true.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Range is not inclusive of the end.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So if you want to see 1, 2, 3, 4, 5,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: you need to say, okay, go from 1 to 6,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: because 5 plus 1 is 6.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So range is not inclusive of the end of the range.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: That's why I have num plus 1.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: But why did I make this for loop?

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: That's pretty easy, because I want to say,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: for i in range 1 and n plus 1,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: oops, colon, print i.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Look, it will give them one by one to me.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: And I have an empty bowl.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: I made it here. I said, final string is an empty bowl.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: I will take them one by one, put them in the empty bowl.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Very easy. How do I do that?

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Well, my empty bowl is not going to be empty for a long time,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: because every time I will add i to it,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: but in its string format.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Remember that final string is a string.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So you can't add a string to a number.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: i is a number from what you can see here.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: I need to convert it to a string to be able to add it to another string.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So every time when i is 1, final string is still empty.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So empty plus 1 is a bowl with 1 in it.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Go up. This is 2 now.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So a bowl with number 1 in it plus 2

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: is a bowl with number 1 and number 2 in it.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Go up. 3.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: A bowl with number 1 and number 2 in it plus number 3, and so forth.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: And the story continues.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So once you have added everything,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: all you need to do is, let's make sure I type this correct,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: you print the final string.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Let's run this code.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Hopefully it works. Fingers crossed.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: And you will see that it's not going to run.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Why? The reason is, I told you in the beginning,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: I said, this is the hammer that you have bought.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Beautiful. You have a hammer.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: But you can't just hang a frame by a sitting hammer.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: You need to use that hammer. And that's here.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: So after I have this hammer prepared,

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: I need to say, okay, print consecutive numbers.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Let's make sure I'm getting it right on n.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: I'll just copy. Yeah, that's the right one.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: If I run this now, it means that I had a hammer and I used that hammer.

chunks.title: Print Function： Hackerrank ｜ Python ｜
chunks.text: Congratulations. That worked.
